p: There is a mounting body of evidence that the dietary intake of infants has an important role in shaping their lipid metabolism [ 1, 2, 3] at a molecular level [ 4, 5, 6]. Specifically, there is evidence that the lipid profile in the circulation of formula-fed infants differs considerably to that of breastfed infants by three months of age [ 6, 7, 8]. This is consistent with evidence that the milk consumed is associated with the lipid profile in infants [ 9, 10, 11, 12], children [ 13] and adults [ 14, 15, 16]; as well as with data from a non-human primate that the metabolism of fats and cholesterol is associated with diet after birth [ 17, 18].
